title-group.article-title: Theoretical analysis of the kinetic performance of laboratory- and full-scale composting systems

article-meta.aff: 1Departamento de Ciências e Engenharia do Ambiente, Faculdade de Ciências e Tecnologia, Universidade Nova de Lisboa, Quinta da Torre, Caparica, Portugal
2Unidade de Ambiente e Recursos Naturais, Instituto Nacional de Investigação Agrária, Instituto Nacional de Recursos Biológicos, I.P., Lisboa, Portugal
3Departamento e Centro de Química e Bioquímica, Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade de Lisboa, Lisboa, Portugal

author-notes.corresp: Marco Baptista, Departamento de Ciências e Engenharia do Ambiente, Faculdade de Ciências e Tecnologia, Universidade Nova de Lisboa, Quinta da Torre, 2829-516 Caparica, Portugal Email: marcohcbaptista@gmail.com

abstract.p: Composting research at laboratory-scale is critical for the development of optimized full-scale plants. Discrepancies between processes at laboratory-scale and full-scale systems have been investigated in terms of heat balances, but a kinetic analysis of this issue is still missing. In this study, the composting rate at laboratory-scale was, on average, between 1.9 and 5.7 times faster than in full-scale systems for a set of published studies using municipal solid waste, food waste or similar materials. Laboratory-scale performance and full-scale systems were limited to 71 and 46%, respectively, of their maximum potential due to poor management of environmental process conditions far from their optimum. The main limiting environmental factor was found to be moisture content, followed by temperature. Besides environmental factors, waste composition and particle size were identified as factors accounting for kinetic differences between laboratory- and full-scale systems. Overall, this study identifies those factors that affect the kinetics of the composting process most and revealed a significant margin for reducing process time in full-scale composting.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Composting research studies are far more numerous at laboratory-scale than in full-scale systems. The higher costs, smaller degree of control and high labour inherent to the study of full-scale composting systems (Hogan et al., 1989; Mason and Milke, 2005a; Petiot and de Guardia, 2004) have promoted an increased choice for laboratory-scale studies.

The central aim when designing laboratory- or pilot-scale systems is to produce an apparatus in which field-like behaviour can be simulated (Hogan et al., 1989). In fact, these small-scale composting studies are often performed with the aim of producing data for the design of full-scale systems (Chang et al., 2006; Hamelers, 2004; Haug, 1993; Keener et al., 1997; Korner et al., 2003; Richard, 1997; Tseng et al., 1995; Yu et al., 2009). However, the performance of small-scale composting studies typically involves a certain loss of the reality that is inherent to the full-scale (Mason and Milke, 2005a). For example, discrepancies in terms of heat balances between small-scale and full-scale systems (Mason and Milke, 2005a, 2005b; Petiot and de Guardia, 2004) highlight the importance of recreating elements of the full-scale environment in the laboratory as faithfully as possible.

Kinetics is another key aspect that should be compared in laboratory- and full-scale composting. At full-scale, kinetics is a central issue. In fact, there are different process management options in full-scale composting (Finstein, 1992) but, in most of them, the priority is maximizing decomposition rate. A simple qualitative analysis of composting time courses indicates that the composting rate in full-scale systems is lower than in laboratory-scale studies (see, for example, data from Fricke and Muller (1999), Huang et al. (2000), Beck-Friis et al. (2003), Briski et al. (2007) and Baptista et al. (2010)). However, a systematic study that compares the kinetics between laboratory- and full-scale systems and identifies the main factors that limit the efficiency of full-scale plants is lacking.

In the present study, the kinetics in full-scale and in laboratory-scale composting systems were investigated. The differences between the kinetics of full- and laboratory-scale systems were quantified and the causes for those differences were addressed, by evaluating the relative importance of environmental operational conditions, as compared with other factors. To achieve these objectives, the kinetic rate constants from our own experimental work (Baptista et al., 2010, 2011) and from a set of studies selected from the literature were estimated and corrected for temperature (T), moisture content (MC), oxygen concentration ([O2]), and free air space (FAS), which are the factors most commonly considered in composting modelling (Mason, 2006). Two closely-related mathematical kinetic models were used for this purpose.

sec.title: Composting model
sec.p: Two closely-related models based on first-order kinetics for the decay of biodegradable volatile solids (BVS) were used to study the kinetics of the composting process. The simpler model (Equation (1)) did not take in account environmental factors, i.e., data was fitted to a simple exponential decay. The uncorrected rate constant obtained (k′) is affected by system design, type of material under treatment, operation performance, and any other factor that may affect the overall process performance. Thus, k′ is an apparent rate constant that represents the observed rate of the composting process, where any limitations to the composting process imposed by less than optimal environmental conditions are reflected in a lower k′. This corresponds to the rate constants normally found in the literature.

where (VSconsumedt) is the amount of volatile solids (VS) consumed at time t (%, in relation to the total initial VS content); [BVSo] is the total amount of biodegradable volatile solids (BVS) in the initial substrate (fractional, [0–1], on a volatile solids basis); k′ is the uncorrected (or apparent) first-order reaction rate constant (day−1); t is time (days).

Alternatively, a more complex model (Equation (2)) was used where rate constants were corrected for the process operating conditions. Mason (2008b) corrected reaction rate constants for T for the purpose of evaluating substrate degradation profiles obtained at varying T conditions. The inclusion of MC and [O2] in the correction procedure was also suggested by this author. Essentially, by describing the composting rate dependence on one environmental parameter and by monitoring this parameter along the composting process, the rate constant can be corrected for that parameter; that is, it can be calculated on a comparable basis, which is independent from the process conditions that refer to that parameter. Therefore, the corrected rate constant (k) is characteristic of the composting process run under optimal environmental conditions, since the environmental conditions were accounted for in its estimation. k gives an estimate of how far in the stabilization process (VS consumption) one could get in each plant if the influencing factors under consideration were set under optimal conditions, namely if they did not limit the kinetics of the process. Theoretically, if all parameters that affect process rate and the corresponding dependence relationships were known, a universal corrected rate constant for the composting process would be obtained.
where F(T), F(MC), F(O2) and F(FAS) are the environmental correcting factors, and k is the corrected first-order reaction rate constant (day−1).
These models (Equations (1) and (2)) were described in further detail by Baptista et al. (2010, 2011) and in the Electronic appendix. k′ and k are inter-related through Equation (3):
where F(TOT) represents the combined effect of all the limitations considered herein (fractional, [0–1]) (see the Electronic appendix).

sec.title: Source data
sec.p: The estimation of k was made from the experimental data of composting trials carried out by ourselves and others, at both laboratory- and full-scales. Studies selected for this analysis (see Section EA2 of the Electronic appendix) complied with the following criteria:

list-item.p: Monitoring of the composting process allowed estimation of the amount of biodegradable volatile solids consumed throughout the process.

Composting material was food waste, municipal solid waste or dog food (according to Van der Gheynst et al. (1997), dog food is quite similar to food waste, because of its similar fat, fibre and protein contents).

Data for T, MC, [O2] and FAS throughout the process was available. When unavailable, assumptions had to be made for data treatment, based on the information given by the original authors (these assumptions are described in the Electronic appendix).

When more than one data set was available from the selected references, only one was chosen for analysis, which was, in most cases, the one closest to the optimum conditions for composting. This applies mainly to laboratory-scale studies in which different experimental conditions were studied.

sec.p: Data from the selected references was used either directly, when available in a numerical form, or digitized with the software Engauge Digitizer, version 4.1, when only available in graphical format.

sec.title: k and k′ estimation
sec.p: For each of the selected studies, Equations (1) and (2) were used to estimate k′ (uncorrected first-order constants) and k (first-order rate constants corrected for the effects of T, MC, [O2] and FAS), respectively, as explained by Baptista et al. (2010). Other model parameters, namely [BVSo], were also estimated in some situations (see Table 1).

caption.p: Values of k and k′ estimated for full- and laboratory-scale composting studies.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Please refer to the Electronic appendix for further description of the studies.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Studies where [BVSo] was estimated from the authors’ data are marked with *. Otherwise, [BVSo] was fixed at 0.62 (marked with **) or it was estimated by the original authors (no mark). For further information on the estimation of the 0.62 value, refer to Baptista et al. (2010).

fn.label: c
fn.p: No values are presented when the uncorrected rate constants (k′) used were estimated by the original authors.

fn.label: d
fn.p: MSW-using studies; in Keener et al. (1997), the number codes after MSW indicate the temperature of the composting trials; for further details, please refer to Keener et al. (1997).

fn.label: e
fn.p: Mean values for MSW-using laboratory studies.

fn.label: f
fn.p: Adani et al. (2000) study was excluded, because a excessively high NRMSE value was obtained in the fit for k estimation.

fn.label: g
fn.p: Hamoda et al. (1998) study was excluded based on a 98% confidence interval.

fn.label: h
fn.p: Mean values for all laboratory studies.

sec.p: The quality of the model fits to the experimental data was evaluated by the normalized root mean square error (NRMSE), according to Equation (4) (Mason, 2008a).
where RMSE is the root mean square error of the differences between the experimental data points and the fitted curve.
Mean k and k′ values were compared using the Student’s t-test.

sec.title: Reaction rate constants
sec.p: The composting data from a set of published studies both at full- and laboratory-scales was analysed from a kinetic perspective. Experimental data and the corresponding fits to the models described by Equations (1) and (2) are shown in Figure 1, for one laboratory- and one full-scale study. In the left panels, the uncorrected rate constants k′ were obtained by directly fitting the experimental data to a first-order (exponential) decay of VS (see Equation (1)). In contrast, when the environmental conditions during the composting process were explicitly taken in account (right panels in Figure 1), the fitting curves obtained did not correspond to a pure first-order equation because the correction factors F(T), F(MC), F(O2) and F(FAS) varied along the process (see Equation (2)).

caption.p: Illustrative examples of the fitting of the composting models (—) described by Equations (1) and (2) to experimental data (•) for k′ and k estimation, respectively: data of Richard (1997) (a) k′ = 0.095 day−1, (b) k = 0.30 day−1; Fricke and Muller (1999) (system Kessler and Luch) (c) k′ = 0.058 day−1, (d) k = 0.112 day−1. Fitting was carried out by minimizing the sum of squares of the residuals between the experimental data points and those calculated by the models, as explained by Baptista et al. (2010).

sec.p: As expected, k estimates were generally higher than k′ estimates (Table 1). In some cases, k was much higher than k′, as in the data of Baptista et al. (2010) for MBT1. These differences were caused by the distance of the operating environmental conditions from optimal conditions – the larger this distance, the larger the difference between k and k′. Conversely, similar k and k′ values occurred in studies where operating environmental conditions were close to optimal (Table 1).

The mean values for k (0.061 ± 0.022 day−1) and k′ (0.028 ± 0.017 day−1) for the full-scale studies (Table 1) were significantly different from each other (P < 0.01). This means that operation of full-scale plants was far from optimal, but it is also an indication that the kinetic model successfully described the composting process in full-scale plants. This indication is reinforced by the fact that the coefficient of variation for k was smaller than for k′ (36 and 59%, respectively); that is, the correction for the environmental conditions caused k to approach a universal rate constant, as expected. If dispersion between individual plants is eliminated by calculating the ratio k′/k individually for each plant, the differences between k and k′ are made more clear - an average value of 0.46 ± 0.21 was obtained, which is significantly different from 1 (P < 0.01). This means that plant operation led to a composting rate that was, on average, only 46% of that operating under optimal conditions of T, MC, [O2] and FAS.

For laboratory-scale studies, the mean values for k (0.24 ± 0.20 day−1) and k′ (0.16 ± 0.15 day−1) (Table 1) were not significantly different from each other (P = 0.31), probably because of the high dispersion among individual k and k′ values. When the average individual k′/k ratios are calculated for each plant, the value 0.71 ± 0.24 was obtained, which is significantly different from 1 (P < 0.01); a value of 0.70 ± 0.20 was obtained for the sub-set of laboratory studies that use MSW as composting material, which is also different from 1 (P = 0.03). Thus, on average, the composting rate is around 70% of one run under optimal operation. The correction made by the present approach was significantly higher in the full-scale compared to the laboratory studies (P < 0.01 for all laboratory studies; P = 0.047 for sub-set using MSW). These results imply that more favourable environmental conditions are applied in laboratory-scale studies, resulting in a less pronounced correction of k for T, MC, [O2] and FAS compared to full-scale studies.

The NRMSE values obtained in this study ranged from 0.6 to 7.6% (Table 1) (the laboratory-scale study of Adani et al. (2000) was excluded from this range and in subsequent analyses, due to its large value, 15.6%, which reflects a low level of quality of the fit). This range compares well with values reported in the literature, namely 0.90–5.73% for composting trials carried out at constant temperature by several authors (Mason, 2008a), and 0.53–4.43% for a large set of substrate degradation patterns which were temperature-corrected (Mason, 2008b). Most of the studies analysed by Mason were carried out at laboratory-scale (two were pilot-scale studies). In the present investigation, the mean NRMSE values for laboratory- and full-scale studies were 2.7 and 4.7%, respectively. The higher NRMSE for full-scale studies was expected due to the higher heterogeneity of these systems.

sec.title: Laboratory composting – where do variations come from?
sec.p: The variation of k in laboratory-scale systems was very large (39-fold), but not in full-scale plants (three-fold) (Table 1). This means that, at the laboratory-scale, there is a difference of 39-fold between the lowest (0.021 day−1) and the highest k study (0.82 day−1) (Table 1) in the time needed to achieve a certain level of degradation of BVS, for the same T, MC, [O2] and FAS operating conditions. The large variation in the rate constants from laboratory composting was not completely unexpected, though. Working with small size systems increases the level of control over those systems but, without standardization protocols, this higher control represents a source of variability – researchers can choose to operate their systems in a wide variety of process conditions. Standardization can significantly reduce the sources of variation, thus improving the comparability of results among laboratory-scale studies. Therefore, these results suggest that there is a need for standardizing procedures in composting studies at laboratory-scale, as previously proposed by others (Mason, 2008c; Petiot and de Guardia, 2004).

The wide variation of k at laboratory-scale leads one to consider that not all the factors that significantly affect k were included in the composting kinetic model; that is, the correction for T, MC, [O2] and FAS was not sufficient to extract a universal rate constant. This evidence corroborates previous suggestions by other workers (Hamelers, 2001, 2004; Haug, 1993) that factors other than those have a significant effect on composting rate. Examples are: (1) the diversity and sizes of the microbial populations in the waste; (2) the spatial gradients of environmental, substrate and microbial conditions; (3) pH, particularly in the initial phases of the process (Smars et al., 2002; Sundberg and Jonsson, 2008); (4) waste composition; and (5) particle size. Although the first three factors may have a significant effect on k, they were not considered here due to insufficient data and/or background knowledge about their effect on composting rate.

In this study, it appears that waste composition is a key factor contributing for the k variation between laboratory- and full-scale studies. A k of 0.056 ± 0.031 day−1 was obtained for the laboratory studies that use MSW in Table 1 (excluding the Adani study), which is similar to the average k in full-scale studies (0.061 ± 0.022 day−1). In addition, k was significantly different for the set of laboratory studies that use MSW from those that use food waste, 0.056 ± 0.031 day−1 and 0.328 ± 0.205 day−1 respectively (P < 0.01). To further elucidate the importance of waste composition on composting rate, it is prudent to consider the study of Komilis (2006), which performed separate composting trials for food waste, mixed paper and yard waste. The k range obtained after analysing the data of Komilis (2006), as described in Table 2 (0.022, 0.070 and 0.088 day−1 for mixed paper, yard waste and food waste, respectively), was much narrower than the overall k range observed in the present study (0.021 to 0.82 day−1) (Table 1). Also important is the fact that two or even three of these components were generally mixed together in the studies analysed here. Therefore, the differences in k that may have arisen from different waste compositions are likely to be even smaller than those differences obtained from the data of Komilis (2006). In conclusion, while the evidence coming from the studies present in Table 1 indicates that waste composition was a key factor to explain the dispersion in the k values of laboratory studies, the causal evidence from the Komilis well controlled study down-plays the importance of waste composition. Altogether, we conclude that waste composition was a contributing factor for the dispersion between full-scale and laboratory studies.

caption.p: The k values estimated from the data of Komilis (2006) for a food waste recipe, yard waste and mixed paper.

tr.td: Food waste recipe: milk + cooked pasta + hamburger + lettuce + raw potatoes + carrots in equal amounts (wet weight basis) + 10 to 15% (v/v) aluminium packing material
Mixed paper corrected for a C/N = 25–30 shredded to 3–4 cm square pieces : MSW compost; 10 : 1 (dry weight basis) + 10–15% (v/v) aluminium packing material
Yard waste – grass clippings : leaves; 1.5 : 1 (dry basis) + 10–15% (v/v) aluminium packing material

fn.label: a
fn.p: [BVSo] were estimated from the author’s data.

sec.p: With respect to particle size, information was not given in some of the studies selected for the present investigation, but analysis of the available information showed that particle size was very variable. In some cases, particle size went up to 50 mm, in other cases it did not go above 10 mm (cf. Electronic appendix). Particle size patterns along the composting process must also have been very variable, since factors such as the type of waste, the pre-treatment processes, the type of composting system or the operating conditions, could all influence the particle size variation patterns throughout the process.

Currently, there is no method that has been proven to accurately quantify particle size experimentally (Hamelers, 2001, 2004). Nevertheless, an attempt was made here to correlate k with maximum particle size for the laboratory-scale studies for which this information was available (Figure 2). For these studies, there was a trend where k increased with decreasing maximum particle size, even though other factors such as waste composition and microbiological or gradient aspects were not accounted for.

caption.p: Comparison of k values obtained for laboratory-scale studies with the maximum particle size of the composting materials (according to the information given in the Electronic appendix).

sec.p: Results shown in Figure 2 are in line with those obtained by others, which indicate that large particle sizes create a limitation to aerobic biodegradation. Simulations by Hamelers (2001) and Tseng et al. (1995) predicted that anaerobic conditions would occur inside substrate particles greater than 0.25 mm in diameter, even with high oxygen concentrations in the gas phase surrounding the particles. Similarly, Kovács et al. (2007) concluded that only the outer 0.5 to 1 mm layer in sewage sludge could be considered as biodegrading actively in composting, due to oxygen diffusion limitations. Nielsen and Berthelsen (2002) also obtained results that indicate that the oxygen diffusion rate in composting particles is limiting for distances larger than 1 mm, and Trémier et al. (2009) showed the importance of particle size adjustment in sludge composting, operated by changing the bulking agent particle size.

Taking in account these findings, one is led to conclude that particle size may have been a significant limiting factor to composting rate in most of these studies, and was probably a major source of variation between the k values studied here. In the future, it would be important to pursue the study of the effect of particle size on composting rate. The development of an experimental methodology that allows particle size patterns to be accurately monitored throughout the composting process would be particularly useful. Until then, particle size should be standardized in laboratory-scale studies, in order to improve comparability of results.

Lastly, the fact that the composting kinetic model was able to extract similar k values for the laboratory- and full-scale MSW studies (cf. Table 1) suggests that the laboratory-scale studies could recreate the intrinsic biological kinetics of full-scale composting systems.

sec.title: Is laboratory-scale composting faster than full-scale composting?
sec.p: The results obtained in this study confirm the intuitive hypothesis that composting rate in laboratory-scale studies is generally higher than in full-scale plants. The process rate differences were quantified from the mean k′ values for full-scale, laboratory-scale (all studies), and laboratory-scale studies that use MSW (Table 1) (0.028 ± 0.017 day−1, 0.16 ± 0.15 day−1 (P < 0.01) and 0.052 ± 0.025 day−1 (P = 0.03), respectively). By using these values in Equation (1), it is shown that laboratory-scale composting was, on average, 5.7 times (or 1.9 times if only MSW-using studies are considered) faster than full-scale composting. This means that the length of time needed to reach a certain level of decomposition of [BVSo] in full-scale systems was around 5.7 times (or 1.9 times for MSW-using studies) longer than the time needed in laboratory-scale systems.

Lastly, when k′/k values were used in Equation (3), it was found that management of the environmental process conditions of T, MC, [O2] and FAS was, on average, around 55% more efficient in laboratory-scale than in full-scale systems (or 51% more efficient if only MSW-using laboratory studies are considered).
Overall, these results show that there is a large margin for improvement in the kinetic performance of real-scale systems.

sec.title: Full-scale composting – most important environmental factors
sec.p: One of the conclusions drawn from the preceding section was that management of environmental factors was worse at full-scale than at laboratory-scale. The high degree of control in laboratory-scale studies makes it easy to maintain the environmental factors at the desired levels, which depend on the specific objectives of each study. At full-scale though, environmental factors should be as close to optimum levels as possible, in order to maximize process rate. However, in practice, there are many constraints associated with the management of environmental conditions at full-scale (Baptista et al., 2011). Therefore, it is important to know which environmental factors are the most limiting and, consequently, which have a larger effect on the correction of k. This was achieved by correcting the rate constants individually for each environmental factor (Figure 3). T and MC emerged as the two main limiting factors of the composting rate, because they were not operated at optimal conditions. On average, the rate of composting as measured by the rate constant k would be 17 and 56% higher if optimal T and MC were used. On the other hand, variation of FAS and O2 within the operational range was predicted not to have a significant effect on the composting rate. Therefore, if managers of full-scale plants wish to increase the composting rate, a specific recommendation from this work is that they should focus their attention on monitoring T and MC values throughout the composting process and make the necessary interventions to control these environmental factors.

caption.p: Analysis of the impact of each of the environmental factors on the determination of k in the full-scale systems. This analysis involved the quantification of the increase on k, relative to k′, due to the correction by each environmental factor in separate. k obtained by correcting for the effect of one single environmental factor is identified by the respective environmental factor; k was also determined by including simultaneously all environmental factors. k′ represents the rate constant uncorrected for any environmental factor. P values are presented for those environmental factors whose correction on k′ is significant (t test).

sec.p: It should be mentioned that one underlying assumption in the present modelling approach is that the environmental correction factors [F(T), T(MC), F(O2) and F(FAS)] are independent from each other. Although this is common practice in composting modelling (Haug,1993), this approach needs to be further investigated (Hamelers, 2001, 2004).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study provides evidence that laboratory composting is generally faster than full-scale composting. Superior performance in laboratory systems was attributed to a better management of the environmental process conditions, which was around 50% more efficient than in full-scale systems. Poor management of moisture content was the main cause of rate-limitation in full-scale systems (accounting for a 56% performance limitation compared to optimal moisture content conditions), followed by poor temperature management (accounting for a 17% limitation compared to optimal temperature conditions). Waste composition and particle size were also identified as sources of differences between laboratory- and full-scale systems. In summary, the present analysis improved the knowledge about the factors that affect the kinetics of the composting process, and quantified both their importance and contribution in full-scale systems.

ack.p: The authors would like to express their acknowledgements to Dr Wolfgang Mueller (University of Innsbruck) for kindly providing access to the report Fricke and Mueller (1999), and to Dr Joana Baptista and Dr Russel J. Davenport (Newcastle University) for revising the manuscript.
